title: NSW gearing up for one of it’s ‘most dangerous’ bushfire days
text:
With a deadly bushfire season looming, prepping your home to be fire-ready is more important than ever.

How to protect your home against bushfires

NSW is facing one of the most dangerous days of the bushfire season to date, with seven total fire bans in place as hot and dry conditions threaten to bring more blazes to the state.

Rural Fire Service commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons has warned people that winds up to 100km/h could cause problems for firefighters by possibly grounding aircraft and contributing to the spread of fires.

Total fire bans will be in place on Saturday for the greater Sydney, Hunter, north coast, New England, northern slopes, northwestern and central ranges areas.

Six of those seven areas are facing severe fire danger.

There were more than 50 fires burning across the state by Friday afternoon, half of which were not contained, Mr Fitzsimmons told reporters.

Almost 1000 firefighters and close to 80 aircraft are currently deployed across NSW to tackle the blazes working alongside bulldozers and other machinery.

“We are shaping up to have a pretty dangerous day tomorrow,” Mr Fitzsimmons said.

“It is shaping up to be one of the most dangerous ... just look at the existing landscape and the amount of fire activity.”

The commissioner said the fact no meaningful rainfall is forecast until the new year is a “sobering signal” for firefighters and affected communities.

“The risk is real, the risk is here,” he said.

“This is no normal fire season and unfortunately the forecast ahead for the coming months are not signalling any significant reprieve,” he told reporters.

Penrith in western Sydney reached a high of 38.3C on Friday while the city hit 37.2C. The average October temperature for the city is 22.2C.

Highs of 35C are expected on Saturday for Newcastle and further up the coast at Kempsey, while Moree in the northeast of the state could reach 36C, the Bureau of Meteorology says.

People have been urged to drink plenty of water and not leave children, the elderly or pets in cars amid the hot conditions.
